[[Mark Mitchell (American figure skater)|Mark Mitchell]]
Sue Hamel [[Priscilla Hill]]
Karl Kurtz |choreographer= [[Mark Mitchell (American figure skater)|Mark Mitchell]]
Jamie Isley |formerchoreographer= |skating club= [[Skating Club of Boston]] |retired = |combined total= 218.30 |combined date= [[2008 Four Continents]] |SP score= 74.08 |SP date= [[2008 Four Continents]] |FS score=145.25 |FS date= [[2008 Cup of China]] | medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry | [[United States of America|United States]] }} {{MedalSport | Menâs [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2007 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2007 Oberstdorf]]|[[2007 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} }} '''Stephen Carriere''' (born June 15, 1989) is an [[United States|American]] [[Figure skating|figure skater]]. He is the [[2008 United States Figure Skating Championships|2008 U.S. bronze medalist]], the [[2007 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2007 World Junior Champion]], and the 2006-07 [[ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix Final champion]]. == Personal life == Carriere was born in [[Melrose, Massachusetts]]. He graduated from [[Wakefield High School (Wakefield, Massachusetts)|Wakefield High School]] in 2007. In 2007, he began attending [[Boston College]] part time, where he is a corporate business major. His cousin, Caroline Hallisey, is a short track speed skater and a three-time Olympian. == Career == Carriere won the pewter medal at the novice level of the [[2004 United States Figure Skating Championships|2004 U.S. Championships]]. The following season, 2004â2005, he made his junior debut. He placed 5th at his first [[ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix]] assignment but was not given a second one. That year, he placed 7th at [[2005 United States Figure Skating Championships|2005 U.S. Championships]] on the junior level. In the 2005-2006 season, Carriere won a gold and a silver medal on the Junior Grand Prix and then placed 6th at the Final. He moved up at Nationals and won the junior gold medal. This earned him a trip to the [[2006 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|World Junior Championships]], where he placed just off the podium. In 2006-2007, he won everything on the Junior level, including both his Junior Grand Prix assignments and the 2006 [[ISU Junior Grand Prix Final]]. After placing ninth in his [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|senior national debut]], Carriere was named to the [[2007 World Figure Skating Championships|2007 Junior Worlds team]]. At Junior Worlds, after placing sixth in the short program, he won the free skate, pulling up to win the event overall. Carriere made his senior Grand Prix debut at the [[2007 Skate America]], where he placed 4th. At his second Grand Prix event, the [[2007 NHK Trophy]], he won the bronze medal. He also won the bronze medal at [[2008 United States Figure Skating Championships|nationals]] and finished 10th in his first appearance at [[2008 World Figure Skating Championships|senior Worlds]]. In the 2008-2009 Grand Prix Season, Carriere competed at the [[2008 Cup of China|Cup of China]] and the [[2008 NHK Trophy|NHK Trophy]], winning the silver medal in China and placing 6th in Japan. In January 2009, he was involved in a car accident but was unharmed. He placed 9th at the [[2009 United States Figure Skating Championships|2009 U.S. Championships]]. Carriere missed the [[2010 United States Figure Skating Championships|2010]] and [[2011 United States Figure Skating Championships|2011 U.S. Championships]] due to recurring [[tendonitis]] and a right ankle infection. == Training == From 2000 through 2009, Carriere trained at the [[Skating Club of Boston]] and was coached by [[Mark Mitchell (American figure skater)|Mark Mitchell]] and [[Peter Johansson (figure skater)|Peter Johansson]]. Following the 2008-09 season, Carriere changed coaches to [[Priscilla Hill]] and Karl Kurtz. == Programs == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! Season ! Short program ! Free skating !
